The project manager should choose options **A. Story testing**, **B. Tests based on behavior and test-driven development**, and **D. Security and performance testing**. 

Option A, Story testing, is a common practice in agile methodologies where each user story is tested to ensure correct implementation. 

Option B, Tests based on behavior and test-driven development, is a software development process that relies on the repetition of a very short development cycle: requirements are turned into very specific test cases, then the code is improved so that the tests pass.

Option D, Security and performance testing, is crucial in any project to ensure that the system is secure from threats and can perform well under a particular workload. 

These testing mechanisms can help ensure the quality and success of the project. Remember, effective project management involves not just managing tasks, but also ensuring quality through proper testing.

After the scope statement and iterative delivery approach have been agreed by all stakeholders, the next step for the project manager is to work with the team to break down the scope into smaller, manageable work packages. This will help to create a clear understanding of what needs to be done, by whom, and when. The work breakdown structure (WBS) is a key tool for achieving this, and the project manager should work with the team to develop a WBS that is appropriate for the project. Once the WBS is in place, the project manager can create a detailed schedule and work assignments for team members, as well as assign requirements to team members as part of the requirements management plan. However, the WBS and work packages are the first steps in creating a project plan and defining the work to be done.
